choices.D: The packet is encapsulated with a header and trailer encoding the ordered list of segments
choices.C: A stack of labels represents an ordered list of segments
choices.B: The MPLS data plane is used to push labels onto IGP routes

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

I just took the test and most questions were totally new. The cisco spri training will also not get you a pass as many questions are harder and not covered.in the training. They have made it much too hard.

choices.E: The routing policies are implemented using route maps.
choices.A: The routing policies affect BGP-related routes only.
choices.B: If you make edits to an existing routing policy without pasting the full policy into the CLI, the previous policy is overwritten.
choices.D: The routing policies are implemented in a sequential manner.
choices.C: You can change an existing routing policy by editing individual statements.

questions.question_text: You have configured routing policies on a Cisco IOS XR device with routing policy language. Which two statements about the routing policies are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
The language is ambiguous, but I believe B and C are most correct.

From Cisco:
Where as IOS route-maps operate as a series of statements which are executed sequentially, Route-policies not only operate sequentially but provide the ability to invoke other route-policies much like a ‘C’-program is able to call separately defined functions.

Selected Answer: BC
It's B and C for me
BC - Routing policies are not implemented in a sequential manner. They are processed in a sequential manner.

Selected Answer: BD
I think BCD must be true. in B there is mentioned CLI, so i think no vi or nano editor is meant. 
in C there is no statement about editor or "conf t" editing, so it may be true. D is surely true.
But as we have only 2 options to choose, I think more correct would be BD
should be B and D. The answer C doesn't mention to use Editor to modify it.

i find this information:Changing or modifying Route policies (or prefix/community sets)
 

As you have noticed when editting RPL's you need to reconfigure the complete policy in the regular CLI. An easier method is using the "edit" option described above.

When you are changing your RPL or prefix-set or any other list that RPL is using, it will trigger a few things:

If the RPL is used for BGP and your peer is not REFRESH capable, it will restart your BGP session.

If the peer is REFRESH capable a full table refresh is executed.

The reason for that is, that the RPL change or say prefix set change could have excluded some routes before that now may need to be imported.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/xr-os-and-platforms/edit-or-rewrite-a-route-policy-on-xr/m-p/3298785#M8954

@pavned B. If you make edits to an existing routing policy without pasting the full policy into the CLI, the previous policy is overwritten - not correct, because when you do like this it gives an error on terminal. However C is correct, it just saying that you can edit (didn't mention anything about nano, vi or etc.)
I think B correct, and C looks not correct, because u can change individual statements only in editor like nano and etc.

choices.B: Router 1 sends up to two paths to neighbor 192.168.1.1 for all routes
choices.D: Router 1 receives only the best path from neighbor 192.168.1.1
choices.A: Router 1 sends and receives multiple best paths from neighbor 192.168.1.1
choices.C: Router 1 receives up to two paths from neighbor 192.168.1.1 for all routes in the same AS

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which statement about this configuration is true?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think D is correct because ther is only the "send" statement and the "receive" statement is missing. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/iproute_bgp/configuration/xe-16/irg-xe-16-book/bgp-additional-paths.html#GUID-3B53DD71-EA19-401F-93CC-79E92ADFB915

Selected Answer: D
D is correct one.

Proposed answer " Router 1 sends and receives multiple best paths from neighbor 192.168.1.1" is wrong. There are options for send, receive or both when setting up additional-paths. Router 1 only sends.

"Router 1 sends up to two paths to neighbor 192.168.1.1 for all routes" this is also wrong. Option "select all" -> all (all paths with unique next hops are eligible for selection)"

Since we do not have any info regarding the iBGP neighbour, we cannot know whether is using additional-paths or not so "C" is wrong.

Correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: A
As of this statement from https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=27573 without subnets it will redistribute classful addresses
"The default cost or metric of a redistributed route is 1 for BGP and 20 for all other protocols. This command will redistribute classful routes into OSPF only if the subnets keyword is not used. There are three general types of classful routes:"

So in the question is asked for all subnets (eg:192.168.0.0/24) to be redistributed need to add subnets at the end

choices.C: Router 1 must have the keyword ospf-metric included in the redistribution command for all EIGRP routes to be redistributed.
choices.B: Router 1 must remove the AS number 1 from the redistribution command for all EIGRP routes to be redistributed.
choices.D: Router 1 must have the keyword metric-type 1 included in the redistribution command for all EIGRP routes to be redistributed.
choices.A: Router 1 must have the keyword subnets included in the redistribution command for all EIGRP routes to be redistributed.

Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is troubleshooting an OSPF issue. Router 1 has a neighbor relationship with router 2. Only router 1 classful EIGRP routes can be seen on router 2. In order for all EIGRP routes to be redistributed correctly, which action should be taken?
